{{taxobox | image = Stockschwaemmchen.jpg | image_width = 234px | image_caption = ''Kuehneromyces mutabilis'' in a dry state | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis= [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Strophariaceae]] | genus = ''[[Kuehneromyces]]'' | binomial = ''Kuehneromyces mutabilis'' | binomial_authority = ([[Schaeff.]]) [[Rolf Singer|Singer]] & [[A.H.Sm.]] (1946) | synonyms_ref = {{cite web |title=''Kuehneromyces mutabilis'' (Schaeff.) Singer & A.H. Sm. 1946 |url=http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=287387 |publisher=[[MycoBank]]. International Mycological Association |accessdate=2012-03-01}} | synonyms = ''Pholiota mutabilis'' (Schaeff.) [[P.Kumm.]] (1871)
''Dryophila mutabilis'' (Schaeff.) [[Quél.]] (1886)
''Galerina mutabilis'' (Schaeff.) [[P.D.Orton]] (1960) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Kuehneromyces mutabilis'' | hymeniumType = gills | capShape = convex | whichGills = adnexed | stipeCharacter=ring | sporePrintColor=brown | ecologicalType= saprotrophic | howEdible=choice | howEdible2=caution}} '''''Kuehneromyces mutabilis''''' ([[synonym (biology)|synonym]]: '''''Pholiota mutabilis'''''), commonly known as the '''sheathed woodtuft''', is an [[edible mushroom]] that grows in clumps on tree stumps or other dead wood. A few other species have been described in the genus ''[[Kuehneromyces]]'', but ''K. mutabilis'' is by far the most common and best known. ==Description== *The clustered shiny convex caps are 6–8 cm in diameter. They are very [[hygrophanous]]; in a damp state they are shiny and greasy with a deep orange-brown colour towards the rim; often there is a disc of lighter (less sodden) flesh in the middle. In a dry state they are cinnamon-coloured. *The gills are initially light and later cinnamon brown, and are sometimes somewhat decurrent (running down the stem). *The stipe is 8–10 cm long by about 0.5–1 cm in diameter with a ring which separates the bare, smooth light cinnamon upper part from the darker brown shaggily scaly lower part. This type of stem is sometimes described as "booted". *This species always grows on wood, generally on stumps of broad-leaved trees (especially beech, birch and alder), and rarely on conifers. *It is found from April to late October, and also in the remaining winter months where conditions are mild. It is often seen at times when there are few other fungi in evidence. ==Range== Kuehneromyces mutabilis is found in Australia, Asia (in the Caucuses, Siberia, and Japan), North America, and Europe. In Europe, it can be found from Southern Europe to Iceland and Scandinavia. ==Possibility of confusion with deadly species== The caps of this mushroom can be fried or used for flavouring in sauces and soups (the stems being considered too tough to eat). ''K. mutabilis'' cannot be recommended as an edible mushroom as there is a real possibility that it could be confused with the deadly poisonous ''[[Galerina#Notable species|Galerina marginata]]'', even by people who are quite knowledgeable. Although a typical ''K. mutabilis'' is easily distinguished from a typical ''G. marginata'' by the "booted" stipe which is shaggy below the ring (see photos), this character is not reliable and ''G. marginata'' can also have scales. The main differences are: [[Image:Galerina marginata 051106Bw.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''[[Galerina#Notable species|Galerina marginata]]'' (potentially fatal)]] [[Image:Kuehneromyces mutabilis 031111Bw.jpg|thumb|180px|right|''Kuehneromyces mutabilis'' (good edible)]] *while they are both hygrophanous, ''K. mutabilis'' dries from the centre outwards (so having a lighter colour in the centre) and ''G. marginata'' dries from the edge inwards, *the stem below the ring is scaly below the ring in ''K. mutabilis'', but normally fibrously silky in ''G. marginata'', *''K. mutabilis'' has a pleasant mushroom smell and mild taste, whereas ''G. marginata'' tastes and smells mealy. ==References== {{Reflist}} *This article is partly translated from the German page. *Marcel Bon : ''The Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and North-Western Europe'' (Hodder & Stoughton, 1987). {{ISBN|0-340-39935-X}} *Régis Courtecuisse, Bernard Duhem : ''Guide des champignons de France et d'Europe'' (Delachaux & Niestlé, 1994-2000). {{ISBN|2-603-00953-2}} ==External links== *[http://www.mykoweb.com/Pholiota/species/Pholiota_mutabilis.html Pholiota mutabilis], from [[Alexander H. Smith|Smith AH]] & Hesler LR. (1968). The North American Species of ''Pholiota''. (Archived at ''Mykoweb.com''.) *[http://www.mushroomexpert.com/pholiota_mutabilis.html ''Pholiota mutabilis''] by Michael Kuo, ''MushroomExpert.Com'', November, 2007. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120510131449/http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6630.asp Kuehneromyces mutabilis] by Roger Philips, ''RogersMushrooms'' (website). *[http://healing-mushrooms.net/archives/kuehneromyces-mutabilis.html “''Kuehneromyces mutabilis''”] by Robert Sasata, ''Healing-Mushrooms.net'', February, 2008. {{Taxonbar|from=Q732640}} [[Category:Edible fungi]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1871]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Strophariaceae]]
